medium: Synthetic, silk; strip woven, supplementary weft patterning
title: Man's cloth
text:
Asante weavers produce luxurious, richly patterned garments that are worn only at formal or ceremonial gatherings such as weddings, funerals, or the enthronement of a chief. These cloths are popularly called 'Kente' (from <I>kenten<I>, basket), a name given to them by 19th century traders that may refer to the basketweave effect of alternating stripe and pattern blocks. Within the Asante culture, however, a cloth such as this would be referred to as <I>Nsaduaso<I>, a cloth of high quality that a man of means might purchase. 

Individual cloths are given names based on the stripe pattern of the ground cloth. This man's cloth is woven in the <I>nyankonton<I> design, which translates literally as "God's eyebrow" and symbolizes the beauty and mystery of the rainbow. This exceptional cloth is an example of  <I>adweneasa<I>, a type of kente in which the ground cloth is totally covered with design motifs.

To learn more about Kente please visit the exhibition <I>Woven Splendor: Kente Cloth from West Africa<I> currently on view in Gallery 255.
description: nineteen strips sewn together; ground fabric is maroon, blue, yellow and green striped with overall woven geometric patterns in black, yellow, green and blue
creditline: Gift of funds from the Regis Foundation
